title: Best Chocolate Brands for Carnegie IGA Retail
text:
As a member of the IGA grocery team in Carnegie, Melbourne, I recently undertook a study to identify the best chocolate brands to stock in the store. According to 2021 Australia Census, Carnegie has very diverse population, including a significant number of Colombian customers who often visit our store for their favorite goods. To cater to the local market effectively, I set out to explore chocolate brands based on various factors to guide our purchasing decisions.
The data for this analysis was sourced from the Flavors of Cacao website, which contains ratings for over 2,000 dark chocolate bars. It includes details about the company, country of origin, cocoa percentage, and ratings. Before diving into the analysis, let’s have a look at Table 1 to see the key variables in the dataset:




Table 1: Data Dictionary for Chocolate Dataset










Variable
Description




ref
Reference ID; the highest numbers indicate latest entries.


company_manufacturer
Name of the company and the manufacturer.


company_location
Location where the company is based.


review_date
Year the chocolate bar was reviewed.


country_of_bean_origin
Country where the cocoa beans originated.


specific_bean_origin_or_bar_name
Specific bean or bar name.


cocoa_percent
Cocoa percentage (% chocolate).


ingredients
Ingredients (e.g., B = Beans, S = Sugar, C = Cocoa Butter).


most_memorable_characteristics
Summary of the bar’s most memorable characteristics.


rating
Rating on a scale from 1 to 5.








Firstly, my analysis focus on top chocolate companies based on their average ratings. For this, I filtered out companies with fewer than 10 reviews and considered only those with an average rating above 3.25 to ensure the top-rated chocolates. From distribution of these ratings, visualized in Figure 1, we can infer that Idilio and Soma are standout premium chocolate companies, each maintaining a consistent average rating above 3.5.








Figure 1: Distribution of Ratings by Chocolate Company





I then examined whether there was a relationship between cocoa percentage and the chocolate ratings. Interestingly, Figure 2 shows a negative trend: higher cocoa content tends to be associated with lower ratings. This suggests that consumers would prefer chocolates with a balanced flavor, and other ingredients besides cocoa content also play a crucial role in customer satisfaction.








Figure 2: Relationship Between Cocoa Percentage and Rating





Taking into account local preferences, I analyzed chocolate brands originating from Australia and Colombia, since there is very few chocolate brands from other nationalities in Carnegie (India, China, Greece, Malysia, etc.) and they are not highly rated. Brands from Australia and Colombia in Figure 3 consistently ranked high in terms of quality and ratings, suggesting that stocking chocolates from these countries would be well-aligned with the tastes of our local customers.








Figure 3: Chocolate Ratings based on Local Resident Nationality





In summary, this analysis provides several meaningful insights. Stocking premium chocolate brands like Idilio and Soma could greatly benefit our store due to their consistent high ratings and reputations. Additionally, chocolates with a balanced cocoa content would be more preferable rather than those with an excessively high percentage. Finally, including top-rated chocolates from Australia and Colombia would likely resonate with our local customer base, enhancing customer satisfaction and optimizing sales.

References

Australian Bureau of Statistics - Carnegie 2021. https://www.abs.gov.au/census/find-census-data/quickstats/2021/SAL20498.
Flavors of Cacao. https://flavorsofcacao.com/.
